intro: Odontarrhena peltarioidea, commonly known as the African sand fennel, is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic compounds and compound umbels. It is native to southern Africa, where it thrives in sandy or gravelly soils. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring narrow, linear leaves and yellow flowers that bloom in summer. It is often used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory and digestive properties. Its structure and chemical composition make it an important species in both ecological and ethnobotanical contexts.
